The solution to this exercise must be your own work. You may not share your solutions with anyone else. See also the note on dishonest behavior on the course website: https://crypto.ethz.ch/ teaching/DM23/. 4.1 Case Distinction with Any Number Of Cases Use induction to prove Lemma 2.8: for all k (A1 ∨ · · · ∨ Ak) ∧ (A1 → B) ∧ · · · ∧ (Ak → B) |= B. Which proof pattern have you followed to prove the induction step? 4.2 Element or Subset (⋆) For each of the following choices of sets A and B, decide which of the statements A ∈ B and A ⊆ B are true. i) A = {1, 0, {0}, 1}, B = {{0, 1, 0, {0, 0}}, 1, 10, 0} ii) A = ∅, B = {{∅}, {∅, ∅}, ∅} iii) A = {{0}, 0, {0}, {{0}}}, B = {0, ∅, {{0}}, {0}} iv) A = {∅}, B = {∅, {∅, ∅, ∅}} 4.3 Operations on Sets (⋆) In each of the following cases, give a set A such that a) there exists an x ∈ A such that x ⊆ A. b) A ̸⊆ P(A) and there exists an x ∈ A such that x ⊆ P(A). c) A ⊆ P(A) and for all x ∈ A it holds that x ̸⊆ P(A). 4.4 Cardinality (⋆) Let A = {∅, {∅}, {∅}} and B = {A, {∅}, {{∅}}}. Specify each of the following sets (by listing all its elements) and give its cardinality. i) A ∪ B ii) A ∩ B iii) ∅ × A iv) {0} × {3, 1} v) {{1, 2}} × {3} vi) P({∅}) 4.5 Proving/Disproving Set Properties (⋆ ⋆) (8 Points) Prove or disprove the following statements. Argue using the deﬁnitions. You are not allowed to invoke properties of Theorem 3.4. a) A \ (B \ C) = (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ C) for any sets A, B, C. b) If |P(A) ∩ P(B)| = 2 then |A ∩ B| = 1 for any sets A, B. c) If B ⊆ A and C ∩ B ̸= ∅ then C ⊆ A for any sets A, B, C. 4.6 Relating Two Power Sets (⋆ ⋆) Prove or disprove each of the following statements. a) P(A ∩ B) = P(A) ∩ P(B) for any sets A and B. b) P(A ∪ B) = P(A) ∪ P(B) for any sets A and B. c) A ⊆ B ⇐⇒ P(A) ⊆ P(B) for any sets A and B. 4.7 Special Families of Sets (⋆ ⋆) Let X ̸= ∅ be a set. We deﬁne the following predicate:1 QX (A) = 1 ⇐⇒  |||||| |||||| A ⊆ P(X), A ̸= ∅, A ∪ B ∈ A for all A, B ∈ A, A ∩ B ∈ A for all A, B ∈ A, X \ A ∈ A for all A ∈ A. Prove or disprove the following statements. a) QX (P(X)) = 1. b) QX ({X}) = 1. c) For all A ⊆ P(X), if QX (A) = 1 then X ∈ A. d) For all A, B ⊆ P(X), if QX (A) = 1 and QX (B) = 1 then QX (A ∪ B) = 1. e) For all A, B ⊆ P(X), if QX (A) = 1 and QX (B) = 1 then QX (A ∩ B) = 1. Due by 19. October 2023. Exercise 4.5 is graded. 1This notation stand for the logical conjunction of all statements on the right, meaning the predicate is true if and only if all statements on the right are true.
